item.title: Wedding day for two Moscow activists: they exchanged their vows, then joined the first protest against the war in Ukraine. From @1843mag https://t.co/MWnpWOYBAn

Potassium iodide tablets stop your thyroid from absorbing radioactive iodine. But they do not protect other parts of the body, and they do not protect you from other radioactive elements in the fallout https://t.co/auyBgob4uu
The chaos in Russian markets shows the impossibility of economic “self-reliance” https://t.co/Xl75nW5Wp3

In Russia, the church and armed forces go hand in hand https://t.co/l5RPuUhr5Z

China won't endorse Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, but it won’t condemn it either. Whose side is China really on, and what does its stance mean for global order? The Economist’s Beijing bureau chief, David Rennie, explains https://t.co/J9IGe19Dva
Outrage against Russian aggression puts those who have defended Vladimir Putin on the back foot https://t.co/PsMUxUjIAV
It is unheard of for a serving head of state to be extradited for trial at an international court. What are the chances Russia’s president could face prosecution? https://t.co/WEHCpLXEN6
The world’s first malaria vaccine is scheduled for a roll-out later this year https://t.co/0zOuiQnBt0

“If Ukraine becomes westernised…Russian people will look over the border and they will say, how come our brothers are free and prosperous?”@andreivkozyrev, Russia’s former foreign minister, ponders Vladimir Putin’s fears in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks”https://t.co/Kpyxi9HqMX
Finding evidence of war crimes is the easy part. Bringing perpetrators to justice is quite another https://t.co/ZbJ6gbxSRU
The invasion of Ukraine looks like a turning-point in the fortunes of far-right groups https://t.co/FJ28YS7bK2

“The Kremlin does not understand all these niceties, they understand brutal force.” @andreivkozyrev, Russia’s former foreign minister, explains how he thinks the West should be responding to war in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/Do3YlZB1hu
Russia’s use of mercenaries, who may be used to stop Russian soldiers from deserting, smacks of desperation, @shashj tells “The Intelligence” https://t.co/EmlnP9dNZz
Ukrainian forces in Mariupol are vastly outnumbered, with 3,500 soldiers facing 14,000 invaders, around a tenth of the total estimated Russian force in the country https://t.co/PeRjoC7NsB

In America they are often known as the alt-right, and in Europe as the identitarian right. They often have ties to Russian-sponsored think-tanks and get help from Russian state-backed media and internet trolls https://t.co/CuZXiaa7Y1
The speed and determination with which Europe acted is startling. They found the funds to supply arms to Ukraine, welcome refugees and impose tough sanctions on Russia https://t.co/yKTbwYmGVW
Finding evidence of war crimes is easy. Bringing the perpetrators to justice is much harder https://t.co/VXqjLciQb4
The American Rescue Plan is expected to deliver at least $23.5bn to Puerto Rico. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act will bring yet more https://t.co/9j9EMw1y22
In an unholy alliance, it is helping Vladimir Putin to justify his war at home https://t.co/NWZkSCUv8T
A core management team has been in charge of strategy for the past 22 days, making decisions from aboard randomly chosen trains to avoid being hit by the Russians https://t.co/2JH3GM4iwJ
Politicians all over the world are downplaying their links to Vladimir Putin https://t.co/9JfXNEj2Yp
Authorities say they have already certified 4,000 dead in Mariupol. A deputy mayor believes the current figure could be 20,000, or more. In truth, no one knows https://t.co/kWwjzZjXun

“He is not representing the interests of Russia…he is representing the interests of his regime for him to stay in power, which is contrary to Russian interest.” @andreivkozyrev, the former Russian foreign minister, joins “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/a8I0NtLFXH
People want to leave, but getting out is risky. Talks have failed to produce a recognised humanitarian corridor out of Mariupol, such as now exists in around nine other places https://t.co/qpdmme0pmi

Talks have failed to produce a recognised humanitarian corridor out of Mariupol. Some people are leaving any way they can, often under artillery fire. But the most dangerous escape routes are becoming even more deadly

“The whole of the centre is in ruins,” says an ambulance-service welder who managed to escape. “The worst thing is seeing the corpses strewn across the street. There are hundreds of them” https://t.co/jvwE5oPDnc
Russia’s invasion has shown the West the perils of trading with adversaries. One concern is moral. Another is security https://t.co/4673ExYAyq
In Russia, displaying a Z is beginning to be seen as a test of loyalty to Vladimir Putin and his war https://t.co/Jb4YaQccTB
KAL’s cartoon https://t.co/uuVPGe6pZC
Europe’s ability to stay united will guide both the outcome in Ukraine and the future of the EU https://t.co/rYuxfg6yig

⚡️ There are more than 300,000 members of the official “IT Army” of Ukraine, a Telegram group of volunteer cyber-warriors set up by the government, and an increasing number of unofficial groups.
Their aim is to spread chaos in Russia https://t.co/JHwW3pK7pY

Many pets remain in Ukraine. Kyiv’s metro stations—now bomb shelters—are full of pets snuggling quietly with their owners https://t.co/uRWcZq4Izn

On Monday Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation hearing for a seat on the Supreme Court begins. If confirmed by the Senate, she will be the first black woman to serve on America’s highest court https://t.co/wUpazG7fuh
China’s economy is ten times larger than Russia’s. China has thrived under today’s world order, whereas Russia has only undermined it. The West can exploit this https://t.co/oZYhtxkOSV

Serbia’s rejection of sanctions against Russia is “no surprise”, argues Vjosa Osmani, Kosovo’s president, in a guest commentary for The Economist. She warns the country’s shift towards autocracy has been “gradual and, crucially, deliberate” https://t.co/PH0gdLwIIi

Xi Jinping is not like Vladimir Putin, who has no other way of exerting Russian influence than disruptive threats and the force of arms. What makes China different is that it has a stake in stability https://t.co/unATJThafg
Continued unity within the EU, notably on sanctions against Russia, has given Europe a hard-power relevance it has rarely enjoyed https://t.co/s3ILXNtHek
The prospect of facing legal charges might possibly deter some of Vladimir Putin’s lieutenants from following orders to commit further war crimes https://t.co/zx04cHFy5K
The war has shifted the conversation in Europe towards building “European sovereignty”; something Emmanuel Macron has been saying for years https://t.co/duinVCBSqo
Cancel Dostoyevsky, and you miss peerless insights into nihilism and violence. Banishing Tolstoy means losing a timeless prophet of peace. https://t.co/yaeSy8Zwu5
When his body was found it emerged that he had taken oﬀ his bulletproof vest to give it to a child he was carrying https://t.co/sVSKwMMBlW

“This war is [Vladimir] Putin’s way of testing the democratic world and it is an attempt to break our democratic spirit,” writes the president of Kosovo. Instead, @VjosaOsmaniPRKS argues, it has done the opposite https://t.co/tS5q8Ezomf
Many fear that Russian occupiers will destroy Ukrainian archives or purge them of material that does not fit Vladimir Putin’s view of the world https://t.co/Vi4a5snfKD
